dt: {bc}one who takes a conciliatory attitude and advocates negotiations and compromise

et: Middle English {it}duve, douve, dowe,{/it} probably going back to Old English {it}*dūfe{/it} and a shortened form {it}*dufe,{/it} going back to Germanic {it}*dūƀōn-{/it} (whence also Old Frisian {it}dūwe{/it} "dove," Old Saxon {it}dūƀa,{/it} Middle Dutch {it}duve,{/it} Old High German {it}tūba,{/it} Old Icelandic {it}dúfa,{/it} Gothic {it}-dubo,{/it} in {it}hraiwadubo{/it} "turtledove"), of uncertain origin

The modern English outcome with [ʌ] presupposes shortening of (or variation with) a Middle English form with {it}ọ̄,{/it} itself presupposing Old English {it}ŭ{/it} affected by Middle English open-syllable lengthening. Middle English spellings such as {it}douve,{/it} however, would seem to require an Old English long vowel, as do the Germanic cognates. These issues were pointed out by E. J. Dobson ({it}English Pronunciation, 1500-1700,{/it} 2. edition, Oxford, 1968, p. 514), who follows the {it}Oxford English Dictionary{/it}'s suggestion that the noun is related to Old English {it}dūfan{/it} "to dive, plunge (into a liquid)" (see {et_link|dive:1|dive:1}) and that the forms with long and short {it}u{/it} reflect different ablaut grades of {it}dūfan{/it} (a class II strong verb). Essentially the same solution, without the discussion of the English details, is proposed by G. Kroonen ({it}Etymological Dictionary of Proto-Germanic,{/it} Brill, 2013). The difficulty with this hypothesis is that the noun in Germanic languages uniformly means "dove, pigeon," not an aquatic bird. Another proposal associates {it}*dūƀōn-{/it} with the Celtic etymon of Old Irish {it}dub{/it} "dark, black," Old Welsh {it}dub,{/it} Welsh {it}du,{/it} on the assumption that a dove is "the dark bird." But such a source, usually derived, together with Germanic {it}*dauƀa-{/it} "deaf, senseless" (see {et_link|deaf|deaf}) and Greek {it}typhlós{/it} "blind, dark," from Indo-European {it}*d{sup}h{/sup}ub{sup}h{/sup}-, *d{sup}h{/sup}eu̯b{sup}h{/sup}-,{/it} could not regularly produce a long {it}u.{/it} The {it}Oxford Dictionary of English Etymology,{/it} the etymological successor to the {it}Oxford English Dictionary,{/it} abandons the {it}dive{/it} connection and says simply "presumed to be imitative of the bird's note."
shortdef: any of numerous pigeons; especially : a small wild pigeon
one who takes a conciliatory attitude and advocates negotiations and compromise; especially : an opponent of war

dt: {bc}an American dove ({it}Zenaida macroura{/it}) with a pointed tail and a plaintive coo

shortdef: an American dove (Zenaida macroura) with a pointed tail and a plaintive coo

dt: {bc}a bluish-gray dove ({it}Columba livia{/it}) that is indigenous to Eurasia but has been widely established elsewhere including most of North America and that is the ancestor of many domesticated pigeons and of the feral pigeons found in cities and towns throughout most of the world

shortdef: a bluish-gray dove (Columba livia) that is indigenous to Eurasia but has been widely established elsewhere including most of North America and that is the ancestor of many domesticated pigeons and of the feral pigeons found in cities and towns throughout most of the world —called also rock pigeon
